data.title: Some new content readers. Alpha blend fix for GL20.
data.body:
Added PlaneReader, QuaternionReader and Vector4Reader.
Removed unused variable in ContentManager.ReloadAsset().
ColorReader now reads RGBA bytes in order to make sure it complies with the XNB format spec.
ReflectiveReader should now be able to serialize a private field if it has the ContentSerializer attribute.
Fixed BlendState.AlphaBlend and BlendState.NonPremultiplied in GL20. They weren't using premultiplied alpha blend functions.

data.title: Tombstone support and some small changes
data.body:
Fix android touch issue where there were two touches in one update. It caused the previous touch(s) to get stuck and stay in the collection.

Added support for tombstoning in Android.

Added a call before every draw to create opengl textures for newly loaded textures.

data.title: Platformer Sample does not Render correctly on Android
data.body: Under the OpenGL ES 2.0 profile the platformer no longer renders correctly.

data.title: UserDrawPrimitives no longer work on Android
data.body:
Under the OpenGL ES 2.0 profile UserDrawPrimitives no longer work. As a result the Vector rumble SampleKit does not render. 

The app does not crash but there are allot of Unsupported API call messages from OpenGL. 

It is worth mentioning that it still works under the GL 1.1 profile.

data.title: Android Changes
data.body: Removed log on touch that was causing GC's to occur.  Implemented ShowKeyboardInput by using a alert dialog.  Fix back button logic.  Added Volume button logic.  Fixed PackedValue in VertexElementColor.

data.title: Flip Projection transform with rotation to keep aspect ratio correct in portrait mode.
data.body:
I had to do this to prevent stretching in portrait mode. I see this is a subset of a change you have in the Ipad2_rotate branch already. That branch has other changes related gamecenter UI that don't seem related.

I'd like to receive feedback if someone thinks this will cause problems.

data.title: Unable to compile because GamepadBridge.dll is not signed
data.body:
I am trying to port a game to Linux but unable to successfully compile MonoGame because some assemblies in the ThirdParty/GamepadConfig folder in particular GamepadBridge are not signed with a strong name and is preventing me from compiling the dlls with Mono from Linux.  In addition there is no source code for the assemblies in GamepadConfig in order to sign it.

Error CS1577: Referenced assembly `GamepadBridge, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null' does not have a strong name (CS1577) (MonoGame.Framework.Linux)

data.title: Add vsync functionality to MacOS
data.body:
Adds vsync functionality to MacOS by toggling the SwapInterval in the OpenGLContext of the game window.

Note that the MonoMacGameView forces vsync to false just before the first update (but after Game.Initialize() is called and the graphics are set up), so I force an update to the graphics setting in MacGamePlatform.StartRunLoop.

This is my first contribution to MonoGame (and my first pull request on Github), so please let me know if anything is horribly amiss!

data.title: Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexPositionColorTexture
data.body: A missing reference to Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexPositionColorTexture in MonoGame came up when debugging Krypton XNA

data.title: Updates to Android Texture2D to support GL20

data.body:
This patch contains a fix for the Accelerometer under android.
also change to move the networking over to use UTF8 rather than ASCII. This will need some testing.

```
    private void InitializeGameComponents()
    {
      foreach (GameComponent gc in _gameComponentCollection)
              {                
               gc.Initialize();
              }
    }
```

       bei MemoryMadness.Program.Main(String[] args) in d:\GITs\MonoGame\monogame\EX1_BasicGameWithStateManagement\MemoryMadness\MemoryMadness\Program.cs:Zeile 26.
  InnerException: 

SampleCode:
Here is the Sample i used to convert it to Monogame. In XNA it works!

```
    private void InitializeLevel()
    {
        currentLevel = new Level(ScreenManager.Game,
                     ScreenManager.SpriteBatch,
                     currentLevelNumber, movesPerformed, buttonsTexture);
        currentLevel.IsActive = true;

        ScreenManager.Game.Components.Add(currentLevel);

```

Any hint how to fix this problem?

data.title: iOS Guide.BeginShowKeyboardInput
data.body:
On iOS, the command Guide.BeginShowKeyboardInput doesn't work correctly.

A popup appears with 3 text fields that you can type, instead of one, and clicking on the "Done" button on the keyboard doesn't do anything.

data.title: Add OpenAL support to MonoGame for Mac OSX and iOS, and regression fixes
data.body:
Please do not Merge this yet until it is discussed by the developers because of MonoMac support not being there yet.

This also fixes an issue reported with the BoundingFrustrum and BoundingSphere definitions being reversed.

Fix stencil render targets

Added property value changes to the SoundEffectInstance and other modifications.

Added CreateWorld method to Matrix class

Fix regression with screen changes and IsActive

Fix regression with GetData for RenderTargets

Add OpenAL support for windows

Add support SynchronizeWithVerticalRetrace in Mac OSX

Added two abstract methods Begin and End ScreenDeviceChange to the GamePlatform to coincide with XNA's GameWindow definition.

data.title: Added a few mode XNA 4.0 compatible methods
data.body: Some of these will need to be ported over to Linux/Windows and MacOS.

data.title: Game.Content should have a setter
data.body:
http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.xna.framework.game.content.aspx

Helps with people writing a custom ContentManager.

data.title: Line feeds and virtual-ness
data.body:
http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb197848.aspx says that ContentManager.Load should be virtual. I made that change.

Also, under Linux, line endings were CR only. That hasn't been standard since about Mac OS 7 or so. This commit changed them to CRLF (Windows style), which should be relatively portable (800 pound gorilla effect).

data.title: Unified Game class (and other things)
data.body:
### Goals
1. Consolidate duplicated logic in platform-specific Game classes into a single class.
2. Abstract platform-specific details into a new GamePlatform class with per-platform implementations (see: [Strategy Pattern](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategy_pattern))
3. Full support for IDrawable.DrawOrder and IUpdateable.UpdateOrder.
4. Full support for adding and removing GameComponents during an Update cycle.
5. More robust support for platforms that prefer asynchronous run loops (all platforms but Windows).
### Rationale

The desire for these changes arose primarily out of a need for (3) and (4).  However, the complexity involved in creating a robust and efficient mechanism led to a desire to reduce existing logic duplication and avoid introducing new duplicated logic, thus (1) and (2).
### Details

A great deal of shared functionality between the per-platform Game classes has now been consolidated into a single, shared Game class.  Hooks into platform-specific functionality are provided via per-platform implementations of the GamePlatform abstract base class.

A specialized collection, SortingFilteringCollection<T>, has been introduced to the Game class to manage and synchronize typed lists (IDrawable and IUpdateable) of components.  This collection class processes adds and removes via journaling to allow simultaneous enumeration of "last frame's" items and modification of "next frame's" items.

Game.Run has been overloaded with an out-of-XNA-API version that takes a GameRunBehavior (Asynchronous or Synchronous) to specify which type of run loop should be executed.  The normal, zero-argument version of Game.Run, queries GamePlatform for the default run loop behavior of that platform.  Currently, all platforms except Windows are asynchronous-only and Windows is synchronous-only.  But in principal, most platforms could be extended to support both modes.
### Caveats
1. This is a large patch.  In the end, it seemed easier to get the unification effort over with in one shot, rather than try to break it up artificially.  Still, the size seems regrettable.
2. As with any sweeping change, regressions have undoubtedly been introduced.  We'll be working through these issues as they are discovered, of course, and adding automated tests to help with new regressions in the future.
3. There is a known regression with window/viewport initialization and size changes.  More work needs to be done to ensure that the GraphicsDevice parameters and the actual size of the render surface are kept synchronized.
4. More work can be done to reduce some awkwardness that remains in the Game/GamePlatform interaction.
5. Game can be Disposed prematurely, especially on asynchronous platforms, but it does not yet provide any feedback that it is being used after having been Disposed.  This is noticeable when running samples from the [sample project](https://github.com/CartBlanche/MonoGame-Samples).  (This issue was present before, but the effects are now more pronounced.)
### Miscellany

In the process of doing tests against the [sample project](https://github.com/CartBlanche/MonoGame-Samples), a number of possibly-unrelated changes have been made.  Briefly:
1. iOS VideoPlayer now presents itself using a parent view controller.  There may be backward-compatibility ramifications here.
2. Linux EffectPass now checks for shader4 support in EXT and ARB before calling the plain-GL version (which still may result in an exception if support is not available)
3. Added an 80-column copy of the Ms-PL to the root of the project, for reference and ease of duplication.

data.title: PS3 controller mapping for Linux
data.body:
Working with incorrect mappings was quite painful.

I noticed that there are XML definitions for the controllers, but everything seems to be hard-coded regardless. Perhaps it would make sense to parse those to clean up this bit of code in the future? Is there any reason this is not being done (other than that no one has done it..)?

data.title: Updated the Orientation implementation for Android
data.body:
Note activityattribute must include the following options

ConfigurationChanges=Orientation|Keyboard|KeyboardHidden

data.title: Memory Leak on Android when Orientation Changes
data.body:
There seems to be a big problem with the Orientation change stuff on Android. After reading the documentation the Activity is re-created each time the Orientation/Configuration changes. The means the Game object is being re-created each time, so all the assets are loaded again and again and again each time the orientation changes. 

We need to figure out a way to detect this and keep the same game object/ content manager around  and just swap out the Activity/ AndroidGameView. 

This will not effect people who just use a fixed screen orientation for games as the orientation will not change. however this might be the cause of the Resume issue we have been seeing as well.
